PreparerFirmName.BusinessNameLine1Txt: Batts Morrison Wales and Lee PA

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Operation of a non-profit Christian preschool, elementary, and secondary school pursuing spiritual and academic excellence with Christian families by going the second mile.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Operation of a non-profit Christian preschool, elementary, and secondary school.
IRS990.Desc: The Master's Academy operates a private, non-profit, college-preparatory, non-denominational Christian preschool, elementary, and secondary school.

OtherAssetsOrgGrp.Desc: Interest in leasehold held by TMA Properties Foundation, Inc.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The $1 Million Permanent Endowment is held by TMA Heritage Foundation, Inc. for the benefits, compensation, and resoures of the teaching faculty of the Academy.
The Academy published an ad in the local newspaper of general circulation, the Orlando Sentinel.
The Academy makes grants only to related organizations. The use of grant funds are monitored by regular Board and management review of financial and operational records.

The Academy provides need based financial aid to individuals to attend the Academy. Financial aid recipients are selected based on information provided via an electronic application which is reviewed by the Academy's staff. Financial aid is awarded based on student financial need as verified by an independent third party and is applied directly to the student's account as a reduction in tuition. The Academy monitors each recipient student to ensure that he/she remains an active, enrolled student and satisfies the academic and behavioral criteria for maintaining the financial aid.

The Academy's Board of Directors as a whole served as the compensation committee. In setting such compensation, the Board considered the scope of Dr. Harris' duties which include those of President/CEO, Facilities Manager, Chief Financial Officer, and other administrative duties for all operations of The Master's Academy, including Camp Sparta.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Part I, Line A, columns (a) through (f):
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The issuance reported on the Form 8038 includes Industrial Development Revenue Note (The Master's Academy of Central Florida, Inc.), Series 2015A in the amount of $11,000,000 to refund a prior issuance for educational facility improvements, including issuance costs of $75,626, and Series 2015B in the amount of $8,000,000 to construct and equip an additional educational facility improvement.
Other spent proceeds includes $10,924,374 to refund a prior bond issuance. Of this amount, $320,000 was related to the termination of the swap agreement.

The Academy is reporting in Part I, column (b) the number of contributions received. All contributed items reported at Part I were sold by the Academy in its thrift store in support of the Academy's exempt activities. The merchandise sold in the Academy's thrift store was received by the Academy as a contribution or gift and therefore met the exception to the unrelated business income rules under Section 513(a)(3). The thrift store closed on October 31,2017 and unsold merchandise was donated or disposed.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Academy's top management official and top financial official each review the Form 990 prior to its filing with the IRS. A copy of the final Form 990 is also provided to the voting members of the Academy's governing body prior to its filing with the IRS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Academy's conflict of interest policy is distributed to each member of the Academy's governing body, its officers and its key employees on an annual basis. Each such individual provides an annual disclosure statement indicating that they have received, read, understood and agreed to comply with the policy, certifying that: (1) they have no relationships or interests that present a conflict of interest, (2) they have one or more conflicts of interest that have been fully disclosed as required by the policy and have been properly administered in conformity with the policy, or (3) they have previously undisclosed conflicts of interest and disclosing the details of such conflicts. Any disclosure statements with previously undisclosed conflicts of interest are forwarded to appropriate Academy officials to take appropriate actions as required by the policy.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Academy has adopted an executive compensation setting policy applicable to all disqualified persons, including the Academy's President, officers and key employees. Under the policy, the Board of Directors reviews and approves the compensation levels of all individuals subject to the policy. The deliberations and decisions of the Board are contemporaneously substantiated. The Board utilizes comparability data in its deliberations; updated comparability data is generally obtained every two to three years.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Academy's Articles of Incorporation are publicly available online. The Academy's bylaws, conflicts of interest policy, and other policies are provided to those responsible for complying with them.

An audit of the Academy's financial statements is conducted annually by an independent certified public accounting firm, which has resulted in the issuance of an unqualified opinion. In addition, the Academy is a fully accredited member of the Evangelical Council for Financial Accountability (ECFA) and, as such, subscribes to ECFA's Seven Standards of Responsible Stewardship addressing: (1) operation in conformity with the Academy's evangelical Christian doctrinal statement, (2) oversight by a Board of Directors, the majority of which are independent, (3) submission of complete, accurate, audited financial statements, (4) proper management and financial controls over the use of the Academy's resources, (5) public availability of the Academy's current financial statements upon written request, (6) avoidance of conflicts of interest, and (7) responsible, truthful fund-raising practices.
Change in estimated fair value of interest rate swap contracts 553,315.

The Academy's Board of Directors, or a committee of thereof, assumes responsibility for the oversight of the audit of its financial statements and the selection of an independent accountant. This process has not changed from the prior year.
